Articles.Content:
yeap ok so, see the floating node on the pad? that's a decoupling attach point.

ram that sucker onto the node on the shuttle that sits between the 3 SSME's. its centred. no clamps needed.

just stage it right.

let me know how it goes

more things now for the eyes turned skywards mod for you Budgie

You just need all of your shuttle packs ( the main one, the payloads one) and the most recent version of Raidernicks US Probes pack.

In my experience, if I try do a launch with an inclination with anything but 0Ã‚Â°, the launch will fail. However, if I let MechJeb handle the launch, regardless of inclination, the launch will be ok.

have you tried changing your inclination to rendezvous with a target? I tried something last week with mechjeb but it fired so early and it took all my mono. I almost think the mono engines are weak.

have you tried changing your inclination to rendezvous with a target? I tried something last week with mechjeb but it fired so early and it took all my mono. I almost think the mono engines are weak.

I found that it is best if you do not use the RCS thrusters for manuevers
that's all we got with the 2 engines after external tank separation though.
Remember the reaction wheel? It is strong enough that it can handle shuttle stability for orbital manuevers I just save the RCS thrusters for docking

the built in reaction wheel was what was maintaining the shuttle's stability after the SRBs were jettisoned because it would go out fo control otherwise. it is also strong enough to change orbiter inclination for an inclination changing burn. Mike? Want to assist me?

it may have been an issue with mechjeb. it automatically started throttling up way too early. I'll try both mechjeb and manual inclination changes

- - - Updated - - -

the built in reaction wheel was what was maintaining the shuttle's stability after the SRBs were jettisoned because it would go out fo control otherwise. it is also strong enough to change orbiter inclination for an inclination changing burn. Mike? Want to assist me?

I think you mean "strong enough to change orbiter attitude". Reaction wheels only provide rotation, while a change in an orbital parameter like inclination requires thrust.
